Name: Bernie Shakeshaft
Focus Area: Youth diversion and support (keeping at-risk youth out of detention)
Notable Quote / Contribution: “Founded in 2006 by Bernie Shakeshaft… [with the mission] ‘to keep kids alive, out of jail, and chasing their hopes and dreams.’” (His program has cut youth crime in Armidale by ~38%).

Name: Dr. Judy Atkinson (AM)
Focus Area: Trauma-informed care and healing for Indigenous youth (intergenerational trauma)
Contact: Via We Al-li (e.g. protected email at wealli.com.au)
Notable Quote / Contribution: Over 30 years, she has pioneered culturally informed, trauma-integrated approaches to healing for First Nations communities. “Being trauma-informed takes the guesswork out of why children behave the way they do,” she emphasizes, linking healing with justice reform.

Name: Mick Gooda
Organisation: NT Royal Commission into Youth Detention; Australian Human Rights Commission
Focus Area: Detention reform and Indigenous justice advocacy
Notable Quote / Contribution: “You can’t arrest your way out of this,” he warns, opposing “tough on crime” crackdowns. As Royal Commissioner, Gooda found the NT youth detention system “punitive, not rehabilitative… failing our young people” and urged comprehensive community-centered reforms.

Name: Cheryl Axleby (Narungga)
Focus Area: Reducing Indigenous incarceration; justice system reform (e.g. Raise the Age)
Contact: Via Change the Record media contact
Notable Quote / Contribution: “State and territory governments have been in a tit for tat… it’s promising to see the ACT rise above gutter politics and choose humanity. I encourage all governments to… raise the age to 14 with no delays, and no exceptions,” she said, urging nationwide reform. (Axleby, former ALS CEO, has long argued that “racist law-and-order politics and policies cost lives.”)

Name: Sarah Hopkins
Contact: Via Just Reinvest NSW (media contact available)
Notable Quote / Contribution: “Achieving outcomes like those seen in Bourke not only creates better outcomes for young people… it also produces better financial outcomes and is responsible economic management.” She notes that even a “small upfront investment” in communities yields “positive results… We need to be building stronger communities, not prisons.”

Name: Alistair Ferguson
Focus Area: First Nations community justice models (empowering local solutions)
Notable Quote / Contribution: As a community leader, Ferguson helped Bourke achieve a 40% drop in domestic violence and significant crime reductions. He insists on Indigenous leadership: “Nothing will work… unless the Aboriginal community drives it themselves…justice reinvestment is about building the capacity of communities to drive their own solutions.”. (Maranguka is the nation-leading model of “growing our kids up safe, smart, and strong.”)

Name: Muriel Bamblett (AO)
Focus Area: Aboriginal child welfare and cultural healing (prevention of removals and detention)
Indigenous Affiliation: Yes – Yorta Yorta and Dja Dja Wurrung woman
Notable Quote / Contribution: “Strong leadership is at the heart of meaningful reform,” says Bamblett, who has led VACCA for over 20 years. She champions self-determination – “give greater control to Aboriginal people” in child and youth systems – and initiatives that stop children being criminalised for issues like disability. (Aunty Muriel was NAIDOC 2024 Person of the Year for her lifetime of service.)

Name: Natalie Lewis
Focus Area: Child rights, youth justice reform (particularly for First Nations children)
Indigenous Affiliation: Yes – First Nations (Torres Strait Islander descent)
Notable Quote / Contribution: “We know that holding children in custody doesn’t make the community safe…subjecting children to cruel, inhumane treatment does not make them less likely to offend.” She argues the current punitive approach “actually retraumatises” kids. “If incarceration made us safer, Queensland would be the safest state,” Lewis quips, calling out rights violations and pushing for accountability and humane, restorative solutions.

Name: Toby Finlayson
Focus Area: Youth-led media and storytelling for change (engaging Indigenous youth through music/film)
Indigenous Affiliation: No (works in partnership with Indigenous communities)
Notable Quote / Contribution: Toby has spent two decades helping remote Indigenous communities create media for social change. He has “dedicated his adult working life to Desert Pea Media, delivering Indigenous media programs, effecting real lasting change for young Original Nations peoples, giving them a voice…a bridge to a positive future.” Through youth-led songs and films, DPM projects have empowered countless young people to speak out and celebrate culture.

Name: Dujuan Hoosan
Organisation: (Independent – subject of In My Blood It Runs documentary)
Interview Potential: Unknown (minor; spoke with permission at UN)
Notable Quote / Contribution: At just 12, Dujuan became the youngest person to address the UN Human Rights Council. He appealed for an end to child incarceration: “I want adults to stop putting 10-year-old kids in jail… I want my school to be run by Aboriginal people. I want…to learn strong culture and language.” His brave testimony in 2019 put a global spotlight on Australia’s youth justice practices and the need for Indigenous-led education and solutions.

Name: Karly Warner
Focus Area: Legal advocacy, youth justice policy (campaigning to raise age, reform bail laws)
Notable Quote / Contribution: Warner argues that locking up kids is counterproductive: “Incarceration of children increases crime by compounding the trauma [they] have already been through, and giving them an apprenticeship in the criminal world.” She calls for investments in diversion and support: “If your kid did the wrong thing, what would you want to get them back on track – a program or a prison?” (As Co-Chair of the National Justice Partnership, she leads national efforts to reduce Indigenous youth incarceration.)
